did.abstract: The Czesław Miłosz Papers document the life and work of the poet, essayist and Nobel Laureate Czesław Miłosz. The papers consist of writings, correspondence, photographs, personal papers, audio material, and printed material (including newspaper clippings, printed ephemera and clandestine samizdat publications), spanning the years 1880-2000, with the bulk of the material dating from 1940 to 1989. While some writings, photographs and personal documents pre-date the Second World War, the earliest correspondence dates from 1946.

langmaterial.language: The bulk of the material is in Polish and English. Includes material in French and other languages.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The bulk of the papers were purchased from George Minkoff, 1987 and 1990 and Serendipity Books, 2001. Additional material was acquired by gift from Czesław Miłosz, 1966 and from Farrar, Straus & Giroux, 1995-1997.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Correspondence with Jeanne Hersch, Jadwiga Tomaszewicz and Lillian Valee was formerly restricted until 2010. Five notebooks were formerly restricted until 2010. Correspondence with Józef Sadzik is restricted during the lifetime of John Peter Miłosz.
Boxes 254, 256-261: ‡a Restricted fragile material. Reference surrogates have been substituted in the main files. Consult Access Services for further information.
Box 255 (computer disk): Restricted Fragile Material. Reference copies of electronic files may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.
Box 162 (sound recordings): Restricted Fragile Material. Consult Access Services for further information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Czesław Miłosz Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Czesław Miłosz Papers. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The Czesław Miłosz Papers contain material formerly classed as Uncat MS Vault 489, Uncat MS Vault 577, Uncat MS Vault 736, Uncat MS Vault 797, Uncat MSS 114 and Uncat MS Vault Milosz.

Each of the three largest accessions that comprise the Czesław Miłosz Papers was prepared for sale by Miłosz and his assistants. This organization and identification has been retained where appropriate and the three accessions have been interfiled. Several smaller accessions (including a 1966 donation from Miłosz and donations from Farrar, Straus & Giroux) were interfiled.

Students who assisted in the processing of this collection include Rebecca Henriksen, Zakhar Ishov, Claire Morelon and Ewelina Rudnicka. Visiting archivist Henryk Citko identified and described a portion of the papers.
Electronic files were refreshed into the Yale University Library Rescue Repository. Technical specifications are filed with the media in Restricted Fragile Papers.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Portions of the collection are available on microfilm.

relatedmaterial.head: Associated Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Printed material received with the collection was removed for separate cataloging and can be accessed by searching the library's online catalog.

bioghist.head: Czesław Miłosz, 1911-2004
bioghist.p: Czesław Miłosz, poet, essayist and Nobel Laureate, was born on June 30, 1911 in Šeteniai (Szetejnie), Lithuania and died on August 14, 2004 in Kraków, Poland, at the age of 93. He married Janina Dłuska (1909-1986) in 1944 and they had two sons: Anthony and John Peter. His second wife Carol Thigpen, whom he married in 1992, died in 2002.

Miłosz grew up in Lithuania amid diverse languages and ethnicities (including Polish, Lithuanian, Russian and Jewish) yet retained a strong attachment to his native country and language throughout his decades of life in Western Europe and the United States. As a child and young adult, Miłosz lived under an unstable series of governments and regimes, witnessing the political and social upheavals of the two world wars and rise of the Eastern Bloc. Miłosz studied law at Stefan Batory University in Vilnius (also known as Vilnius University). It was during this time that he published his first poetry in the University publication Alma Mater Vilnensis (1930), and later in a slim printed collection Poemat o czasie zastygłym (1933). He also co-founded the literary group and journal Żagary in Vilnius. While traveling to Paris in the 1930s he met a distant relative, Oscar V. de Lubicz Milosz, who was to be an important lifelong influence.

After completing his studies Miłosz worked in radio, first for Polish Radio in Vilnius (1936-1937). His second collection of poems Trzy zimy (1936) was published during this time. When he was dismissed, apparently for political reasons (perhaps because he included Jewish authors in his literary programming), he moved to Warsaw and worked for Polish National Radio until the outbreak of the Second World War.

During the war, Miłosz produced several clandestine publications including the anthology Pieśń niepodległa ( Invincible song ) and the collection of his poems Wiersze ( Poems , under the pseudonym Jan Syruć). His war-time poems are ironically juxtaposed to the profound trauma of the war and the Nazi occupation of Warsaw. In Świat ( The World ) Miłosz created defiantly serene portraits of faith, hope, love, fear and recovery that are nevertheless testament to the heaviness of war (and in stark contrast to his earlier poems written in Vilnius). This and other poetry from 1936-1945 is collected in Ocalenie ( Rescue [1945]).

After the Second World War, Miłosz became a cultural attaché for the People's Republic of Poland in New York and Washington, D.C. He then accepted a post in France in 1950. Increasingly estranged from the Polish government, he defected in 1951, obtaining political asylum in France. His defection prompted criticism from leftist intellectuals (Pablo Neruda was among his outspoken critics). As Miłosz struggled with his exile and his role as a Polish-language poet in France, he published his analyses of contemporary political upheaval in numerous prose works and regular contributions to Kultura , the Polish-language literary monthly published in Paris. His first post-emigration volume of poems, Światło dzienne , was published by Institut Literacki in 1953. In Poland, his work was circulated chiefly in clandestine copies between 1951 and 1980 since his writing was censored.

Much of Miłosz's prose writing in the 1950s was semi-autobiographical. His early life in rural Lithuania inspired the characters in the novel Dolina Issy ( The valley of Issa , 1955). Zniewolony umysł ( The captive mind , 1953) and Zdobycie władzy ( The seizure of power , 1955), which thrust him into the international spotlight, examined the moral and psychological pressures of life under a repressive totalitarian regime, providing context for his decision to defect. Rodzinna europa ( Native realm , 1959) explores the difficulties of balancing his Eastern European identity and strong attachment to the Polish language with his life as an émigré.

Miłosz emigrated to the United States in 1960. He initially accepted a temporary lectureship at the University of California, Berkeley and was appointed Professor of Slavic Languages and Literatures in 1961. He maintained close ties with the Polish émigré community in Paris, visiting frequently and continuing his association with Instytut Literacki. His works of literary criticism and anthologies of Polish poetry published in the 1960s (including Postwar Polish poetry [1965] and History of Polish literature [1969]) drew increasing attention to Polish literature in Europe and the United States.

In the United States, Miłosz was confronted with the fact that Polish literature was little-known in American circles, referring to himself as "Wrong Honorable Professor Milosz/Who wrote poems in some unheard-of tongue" ( Magic Mountain [1975]). Any trace of self-conceived obscurity vanished in 1980 when he won the Nobel Prize for Literature. The decision to award Miłosz the prize was made just before the democratic Solidarity labor strikes in Poland became widespread (activity that led to the imposition of martial law in Poland and eventually to the democratic change of government in 1989). These events, together with the appointment of Pope John Paul II two years prior, constituted a dynamic affirmation of Polish culture in the world spotlight.

In 1981, Miłosz visited Poland for the first time since his defection thirty years earlier. He was welcomed by immense crowds who celebrated his writing and his recognition as Nobel Laureate. He met with numerous literary and political figures, including Lech Wałęsa (leader of the Solidarity movement and future President of the Republic of Poland).

Miłosz continued to travel extensively after his retirement from teaching in 1978, accepting appointments as a visiting lecturer from, among others, Harvard University and the University of Michigan. He traveled to Poland regularly and his visits were increasingly lengthy until he moved to Kraków in 2000. He continued to publish numerous volumes of poetry and prose works, including translations of his own poetry into English.

Miłosz was a prolific translator to and from Polish and his translations introduced many modern Polish poets (including Aleksander Wat and Anna Świrszczyńska) to English-language readers. He undertook the monumental task of translating portions of the Bible after studying the fifteenth-century Puławski Psalter. His English translations of Polish poetry are are compiled in anthologies such as Czas niepokoju (1958) and Mowa wiązana (1986).

Miłosz received numerous prizes and honors, including the Prix Littéraire Européen (1953), the Neustadt International Prize for Literature (1978), the Nobel Prize for Literature (1980), and a National Medal of Arts (1990). Additional information on Czesław Miłosz is available in standard print and online biographical resources.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Czesław Miłosz Papers document the life and work of the poet, essayist and Nobel Laureate Czesław Miłosz. The papers consist of writings, correspondence, photographs, personal papers, audio material, and printed material (including newspaper clippings, printed ephemera and clandestine samizdat publications), spanning the years 1880-2000, with the bulk of the material dating from 1940 to 1989. While some writings, photographs and personal documents pre-date the Second World War, the earliest correspondence dates from 1946.

The papers document all aspects of Miłosz's professional life and include original holograph and typescript drafts of his major works of poetry and prose from 1945 to1992, drafts or transcripts of hundreds of essays, speeches and lectures, transcripts of radio broadcasts, teaching material, and documentation of his collaboration with Aleksander Wat.

The papers document the domains of Miłosz's eminent career as a poet, writer and scholar of Slavic literature, his creative writing process, the relation of literary figures to historical events and movements of the twentieth century (including the Second World War, the rise of Soviet-influenced Communist rule in Poland, and upheavals in the Polish government in the 1980s), and themes of exile and emigration, particularly as they relate to Polish émigrés in France and the United States. Correspondence and writings directly address the intellectual and political themes that are prevalent in Miłosz's work, such as the incompatibility of totalitarian government and creative expression, the nature of religious faith, and the pain of exile.

Miłosz maintained long-standing association with the Polish émigré community of Paris after he moved to the United States. He frequently corresponded with the affiliates of Institut Literacki. This relationship is also evident in his regular contributions to the monthly serial Kultura . Major correspondents in the papers include Józef Czapski, Jerzy Giedroyc, Jan Goślicki, Zbigniew Herbert, Zygmunt Hertz, Zofia Hertz, Konstanty Jeleński, Aleksander Wat and Paulina Wat.

In addition to Miłosz's writings, lectures and teaching, the papers include sporadic documentation of personal and financial matters. This documentation includes financial records, legal records (especially relating to immigration) and family photographs. Among the printed material that Miłosz collected are many clandestine (samizdat) publications that were produced in Poland despite prohibitive censorship. This collection, while fragmentary, is representative of clandestine publication activity during the 1980s.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into nine series: I. Correspondence, 1946-2000. II. Writings. 1934-2000. III. Interviews, Lectures, Broadcasts and Readings, 1946-1990. IV. Aleksander Wat Memoir and Translations, 1963-1991. V. Professional Papers, 1960-1993. VI. Personal Papers, 1937-1995. VII. Photographs, circa 1880-1989. VIII. Writings of Others, 1928-1998. IX. Printed Material, 1929-1999.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three subseries: Postwar Correspondence, General Correspondence, and Special Congratulatory Letters and Telegrams.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I consists chiefly of Miłosz's incoming correspondence from writers, scholars, publishers, friends, family and fans. The earliest correspondence (filed in the separate subseries Postwar Correspondence) dates from the time period directly after the Second World War when Miłosz worked in diplomatic posts for the People's Republic of Poland in New York and in Washington, D.C. The latest correspondence is from 2000, when Miłosz moved to Kraków, where he spent the last four years of his life.

The general correspondence details Miłosz's life and professional activity from his years in France in the 1950s through the year 2000. Topics of correspondence include practical business (e.g. publication agreements and travel for appearances), political matters (e.g. the plight of suppressed writers and artists in Poland), personal reflections, and literary and philosophical inquiry.
Some files include drafts or copies of outgoing letters, as noted in folder descriptions.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: Additional letters from many correspondents included in this subseries are filed in General Correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The subseries Postwar Correspondence consists of interfiled letters from two categories designated by Miłosz: "Letters, family and friends up to 1950" and "Letters, writers and artists up to 1950." The library's decision to retain this subseries as a distinct group reflects a distinction that made between this early correspondence and other, later correspondence. The time period of 1946-1950 was particularly challenging as his diplomatic service to the Polish government weighed heavily upon him. The subseries documents the early development of his criticisms of Eastern European communism that were later expressed in writings such as Zdobycie władzy and Zniewolony umysł .
Some of this correspondence was printed in Zaraz po wojnie (1998).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series II is organized into six subseries: Poetry, Major Works of Prose, Essays and Other Shorter Works of Prose, Notebooks, Translations by Miłosz, and Works Edited or Compiled by Miłosz.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II consists of drafts, proofs and other material documenting a comprehensive range of Miłosz's writings, including poetry, political analysis, literary criticism, short fiction, memoirs and novels. The papers include original holograph drafts for all of Miłosz's major works (including translations of his poetry and books into English) before the mid-1980s. Some works have multiple drafts, though most files consist of a single, corrected draft. Some drafts are accompanied by extensive notes, such as the holograph transcript of the Puławski Psalter that Miłosz used to prepare for his translation of portions of the Bible into Polish. Typescripts and computer printouts are present for Miłosz's later writings, and material is less comprehensive after the mid-1990s. Computer printouts, dating from the early 1990s on, are generally lightly corrected, in contrast to the heavily annotated earlier holograph drafts. The papers do not include documentation of posthumous publications.

The Poetry subseries includes holograph drafts of most of Miłosz's major works of poetry, including Ocalenie (1945), Światło dzienne (1953), Traktat poetycki (1957), Król Popiel i inne wiersze (1962), Gucio zaczarowany (1965), Miasto bez imienia (1969), Hymn o perle (1982). Corrected typescript or computer printout drafts are present for Nieobjęta ziemia (1984), Dalsze okolice (1991), and Piesek przydrożny (1997). Only the introduction for Kroniki is present. Miłosz's earliest collected volumes of poetry ( Poemat o czasie zastygłym [1933] and Trzy zimy [1936]) are represented only as printed versions.

The Prose subseries includes material of diverse genres: fiction, memoir, history, literary analysis, political commentary, and letters to editors. Major works of prose include book-length works of fiction, memoir, history, literary analysis and political commentary. Material filed under this heading includes holograph drafts of Zniewolony umysł (1953), Zdobycie władzy (1955), Dolina Issy (1955), Rodzinna Europa (1959), Człowiek wśród skorpionów (1962), Widzenia nad Zatoką San Francisco (1969), and Prywatne obowiązki (1972). Typescript drafts are present for History of Polish literature (1969), Emperor of the earth: Modes of eccentric vision (1977), Ziema Ulro (1977), Ogród nauk (1979), and Witness of poetry / Świadectwo poezji (1983). The heading also includes a draft of a science fiction novel unpublished during Miłosz's lifetime ( Góry Parnasu ). Shorter works of prose include essays on literature and contemporary politics as well as short works of fiction and some letters to editors.
The Notebooks subseries includes holograph notes on a variety of topics and drafts of prose, poetry and correspondence.

The subseries Translations by Miłosz consists of drafts and other material documenting Miłosz's translation of others' work, including modern poetry, portions of the Bible and a few prose works (such as those of Oscar V. de Lubicz Milosz).
The subseries Works Edited or Compiled by Miłosz includes drafts, notes and other material documenting poetry collections that Miłosz edited or compiled.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Poetry subseries is organized under two headings: Collected Volumes and Individual Poems.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Individual Poems is further organized into several files reflecting Miłosz's organization and identification of the material: "Juvelilia," "Poems published separately," "Unpublished poems," "New Poems in Polish," and "Translations with Robert Hass." The files Other Individual Poems in Polish and Other Individual Poems, Autotranslations contain drafts of poems (found throughout the Papers) that were not otherwise organized under broader headings. Under each heading, material is arranged alphabetically by title or, for untitled poems, by the first line.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Drafts (holograph, typescript and typescript carbon) of individual poems are filed under this heading. While these poems are not organized according to printed works, some of them were printed in Miłosz's volumes of poetry.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged as received, roughly chronologically.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series III is organized into four subseries: Interviews of Miłosz, Lectures and Speeches, Radio Broadcasts and Material for Poetry Readings. The Interviews of Miłosz subseries is arranged alphabetically by interviewer. The remaining subseries are arranged roughly chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III consists of transcripts, drafts and printed versions of interviews of Miłosz, lectures and speeches, radio broadcasts and notes for poetry readings. Most of the interviews were conducted orally and were re-worked into journalistic or literary publications. The lectures and speeches include Miłosz's 1980 Nobel acceptance speech, formal presentations at conferences or in academic settings and addresses to literary groups and clubs. Some lectures that were later published as essays (and material that may not have been readily identifiable as a speech or lecture) are filed in Series II, Essays and Other Shorter Works of Prose. Radio broadcasts are transcripts or notes from Miłosz's programming on the British Broadcasting Corporation.
In various languages, as indicated by the language of the folder description or folder-level notes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series IV includes audio recordings, transcripts, drafts and other material related to Miłosz's work with Aleksander Wat (including posthumous publication of his works). In the 1960s Miłosz recorded Aleksander Wat's memoirs in a series of conversations. Miłosz and Wat recorded 39 sessions of conversation that correspond to chapters in Mój wiek , though the recordings for sessions 20 and 22 were faulty and were not transcribed or included in the printed version. The series includes some of the original audio recordings as well as a complete set of revised transcripts that were later printed as Mój wiek and translated into English as My century . The papers also include drafts of Miłosz's English translations (with Robert Hass) of Wat's poetry, which were published after Wat's death ( Mediterranean Poems and With the Skin ).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series V is organized into three subseries: Teaching Material, Subject Files and Other Professional Papers and Objects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series V includes documentation of Miłosz's professional activities (other than writing) and consists chiefly of notes for literature courses he taught at the University of California, Berkeley and subject files he compiled. Other material includes curricula vitae, grant applications, awards, diplomas and medals.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged roughly chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Teaching Material subseries consists of notes for courses Miłosz taught on Polish literature and poetry translation. Most of the courses were at the Department of Slavic Languages and Literatures, University of California, Berkeley, though others were visiting lectures at other universities. Some folders include drafts of lectures and copies of student assignments.
Folder titles in quotations are transcribed from the material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series VI includes fragmentary financial records (such as royalty statements, bills and bank statements), a visa dossier compiled when Miłosz emigrated to the United States and family papers. Personal and family papers are present in incidental quantity and constitute sporadic documentation of legal and financial matters. Of particular interest is Miłosz's visa dossier, which he compiled in order to support his application to immigrate to the United States.
Family photographs are filed in Series VII, Photographs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series VII consists of photographs, mostly of Czesław Miłosz, some of which include family members, friends and colleagues. Early photographs (before 1940) include family members and snapshots of Miłosz as a university student and employee of Polish Radio in Vilnius. Family photographs include portraits of members of the Kunat and Syruć families dating to the late nineteenth century and of Czesław Miłosz as a child.

Later photographs are generally of a less personal nature, though they do include snapshots of Miłosz with friends and family in addition to photographs of events and appearances. Many snapshots and portraits were taken by Czesław Miłosz's brother Andrzej, a journalist and film-maker. Fifteen folders of photographs document Miłosz's 1981 trip to Poland.
Miłosz and others wrote notes on the verso of many photographs that identify people and places portrayed.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series VIII is organized into two subseries: Writings about Milosz and General Writings of Others. Each subseries is arranged alphabetically by author.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series VIII consists of manuscripts, offprints, and copies of printed writings sent to Miłosz, usually by the authors. The writings include literary analysis and reviews of Milosz's work, academic theses, poetry, and translations. Offprints and photocopies of articles consist of articles sent to Miłosz or collected by Miłosz. Most articles are on topics related to Polish literature. The Subseries Writings about Miłosz consists of reviews and literary analyses of Miłosz's writing, including several academic theses. Accompanying annotations and correspondence document Miłosz's involvement with the development of some works (such as those of Barańczak, Fiut, Nathan and Quinn); other manuscripts were sent to Miłosz unsolicited. Of particular interest in the Subseries General Writings of Others is the memoir of Zygmunt Guze, excerpts of which were printed in Miłosz's essay "Opowieści pana Guze."

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series IX is organized into five subseries: Writings of Czeslaw Milosz, Clandestine and Samizdat Publications, Clippings and Offprints, Ephemera, and Photocopies of Articles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series IX consists of printed material collected by Miłosz. Writings of Czeslaw Milosz includes clippings from newspapers and journals and individual printed broadsides. Clandestine and samizdat publications include periodicals, collections of poetry and other samizdat publications that were printed outside of the Polish censor's control during the years 1978-1989. The collection, though relatively small, is representative of clandestine publication in Poland during that time. The material documents political, literary and intellectual life under martial law in Poland and the rise of the Solidarity (Solidarność) movement. Clippings and offprints are chiefly about Miłosz and consist of newspaper and magazine articles about his travels, lectures, awards and publications. Ephemera includes announcements for Miłosz's poetry readings, lectures and other events. Photocopies of articles are chiefly on topics related to Polish Literature. Most general clippings are about Czesław Miłosz and include newspaper profiles, interviews and reviews.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photocopies of articles by Miłosz are also filed in the subseries Photocopies of Articles.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged chronologically.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Clandestine and Samizdat Publications is organized under three headings: Serials, Monographs and Fragments. Periodicals are arranged alphabetically by title and monographs are arranged alphabetically by author.
